Spent the week debugging a service mesh issue. Turns out 80% of our infrastructure complexity exists to solve problems we don't actually have.

The best infrastructure is **invisible**. If you're constantly thinking about it, something's wrong.
Shipped a new deploy pipeline. Down from 15 minutes to 2m 15s. The secret? Removed three "optimization" layers that were actually slowing things down.

What if we treated **every** infrastructure change like code? Not just deployments, but access control changes, database migrations, feature flags, on-call schedules.

The audit trail alone would be worth it.

Hot take: Most "platform engineering" is just good old sysadmin work with better marketing. And that's okay.

The value isn't in the fancy titleâ€”it's in treating internal tools with the same care as customer-facing products.
Finally migrated from our hodgepodge of monitoring tools to a unified observability stack. Single pane of glass for metrics, logs, traces. 40% cost reduction. MTTD dropped from 15min to 3min.

Building a CLI that generates architecture diagrams from live AWS infrastructure. Point it at your account, get a clean diagram.

No more outdated Lucidchart docs that nobody maintains. [Early prototype](https://github.com/saixso/infra-viz)
